Поиграв меньше часа я проник всей ностальгией 2004 года.
Да, в игре есть свои недостатки, но блин, ребят, что Вы хотели? Ведьмак 3? Детроит? Если да, то эта игра явно не для Вас. К моему удивлению сервера все еще существуют и на них играют, что лично меня обрадовало!
Что хочу сказать по итогу:"Игра за 20 рублей дает вам возможность проникнуть в то время, когда многие подростки ходили в компьютерные клубы поиграть в нее и насладиться времяпровождением, особенно для не особо взрослых ребят.
Ах, да, еще... Хотел выразить благодарность тем, кто уделил внимание на мой отзыв и прочитал его. 
Удачки вам!:)

Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8–10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you’ve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don’t leave them too long or they’ll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

Counterstrike: Source (included in the Half Life 2 physical game disc box I bought in November 2004), is my most played game, and most favorite FPS, of all time, having over 12000 hours of playtime over many, many years, but for some reason, Steam currently displays my record at 2.2 hours.

CS:S (and HL2) was when I created this Steam account, at that time when nothing existed on Steam except for a log-in system to store games digitally. No community hub, no forums, no friend lists, no achievements, no badges, no trading cards, no account levels, no digital storefront. Just a bare-bones system to key in product activation codes from physical purchases.

CS:S is the game that introduced me to competitive FPS games, and it plays much better compared to CS: Global Offensive, which feels clunky, unrealistic, unresponsive and with a very bad FOV. CS:S has got everything right, and perfect in every way. I spent years hosting my own private and public servers for friends and the public, especially the zombie-survival modded servers that were my most favorite to play.

Beautiful and moral, it preserves the tastiest mechanics of 1.6 with beautiful polygonal ps2 style graphics leaving the gameplay extremely smooth and pleasant, like playing basketball in your underwear.

This game is from when Valve gave a crap about making a playable game. Definitely a ton of bugs, glitches where you can see through walls in certain positions and let's not get started on the doors on assault. But the game feels phenomenal compared to CS:GO nowadays. And as bad as the barrel physics are for actual competitive play, they're great to keep you busy while your friend goes AFK
